questions.text: Match the maneuver used in shoulder dystocia with the description:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. a-4, b-2, c-3, d-1

 

  • Shoulder dystocia is when the head delivers but the shoulders fail to deliver even after 1 minute of delivery of the head

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers

 

  1. McRoberts maneuver: -  
    • Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth
    • This widens the pelvis, and flattens the lumbar spine.
  2. Suprapubic pressure: 
    • directional (45° downward) pressure to the maternal abdomen just above the pubic symphysis.
    • This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned.
    • Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver.
  3. Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina
  4. Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa (somewhat the opposite of Rubin II maneuver)
  5. Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet.
  6. Zaninelli’s maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section.
  7.  Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.
  8. Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders.
  9. Abdominal rescue, described by O’Shaughnessy. where a hysterotomy facilitates vaginal delivery of the impacted shoulder

 

ReF: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

choices.text: Anterior rotation of the symphysis pubis
Displaces the fetal shoulder axis from anterior posterior (AP) to oblique

questions.text: A 24 - year primi presents in active labor at 40 weeks’ gestation. Delivery of the fetal head occurs, but the fetal shoulders do not deliver despite several attempts. To resolve it, McRoberts maneuver was done. Which of the following describes this maneuver?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Anterior rotation of the symphysis pubis 

 

  • Shoulder dystocia is when the head delivers but the shoulders fail to deliver even after 1 minute of delivery of the head
  • The most important and first maneuver done in this scenario is the McRoberts maneuver where the legs are hyperflexed and abducted over the maternal abdomen. 
  • This results in widening of the pelvis as the spine is flattened posteriorly and the pubic symphysis is rotated anteriorly. 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Decreasing the fetal bi-acromial diameter: This happens in the Rubin maneuver where the arm is adducted to the chest thereby reducing the bi-acromial diameter

 

Option C. Separates the maternal symphysis pubis: This does not happen in McRobert's maneuver. In a symphysiotomy, the pubic symphysis is cut/ seperated

 

Option D. Displaces the fetal shoulder axis from anterior posterior (AP) to oblique: This is the mechanism of action in Wood's corkscrew maneuver

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers

 

  1. McRoberts maneuver: -  
    • Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth
    • This widens the pelvis, and flattens the lumbar spine.
  2. Suprapubic pressure: 
    • Directional (45° downward) pressure to the maternal abdomen just above the pubic symphysis.
    • This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned.
    • Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver.
  3. Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina
  4. Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa (somewhat the opposite of Rubin II maneuver)
  5. Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet.
  6. Zaninelli’s maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section.
  7.  Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that requires to pass through the birth canal.
  8. Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders.
  9. Abdominal rescue, described by O’Shaughnessy. where a hysterotomy facilitates vaginal delivery of the impacted shoulder

 

 Ref: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text:
What is the sequence of maneuvers done for shoulder dystocia?

1.Mac Roberts

2.Zavanelli procedure

3. Woods corkscrew

4. Gaskin
questions.solution:
Ans: A. 1,3,4,2

  • In a vaginal delivery, if after delivery of head, rest of the body does not follow, even after 1min, it is called as shoulder dystocia.
  • It is an emergency due to high neonatal morbidity & mortality. 
  • Maneuvers to shoulder impingement in shoulder dystocia-
    • Mac Roberts maneuver: sharply flex on maternal abdomen. This cause straightening of maternal sacrum, rotate it to maternal head & decrease angle of inclination. Suprapubic pressure is usually done along with this maneuver.
    • Rubin maneuver: Sweeping of shoulders towards the maternal chest: reduces the bi acromial dimaeter thereby dis-impacting the shoulder
    • Wood’s corkscrew maneuver - reach accessible shoulder & rotate to maternal chest causing adduction of shoulder
    • Gaskin All – 4 maneuver
    • Fracture of the clavicle
    • Zavanelli procedure: Pushing the head back in the vagina and delivering by a cesarean

Educational Objective:

Remember 2 mnemonics for managmeent of shoulder dystocia

The HELPERR Mnemonic

  • Help: Call for Help
  • Evaluate for Episiotomy
  • Leg: McRoberts maneuver
  • Pressure: Supra-pubic pressure
  • Enter maneuvers: Perform rotational maneuvers
  • Remove: Remove the posterior arm
  • Roll on all 4s (Gaskin maneuver)

BE CALM Mnemonic

  • Breathe: Do not push
  • Elevate the legs into McRobert's position
  • Call for Help
  • Apply supra-pubic pressure
  • enLarge the vaginal opening (give an episitomy)
  • Maneuvers (deliver posterior arm/ Rubin/ Wood Corkscrew)

 

Ref: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: Above what estimated fetal weight is it recommended to do an elective cesarean in diabetic women to prevent complications like shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 4.5kg

The ACOG recommends an elective LSCS for fetuses weighing  > 5kg (in non diabetic mothers) and > 4.5kg (in diabetic mothers) to avoid the risk of birth trauma

Educational Objective

  • As per the ACOG , an elective cesarean is recommended if the estimated fetal weight is > 5kg and in diabetic mothers, this cut off is lower (4.5 kg) to reduce the risk of shoulder dystocia and birth injuries

 

Ref: Page 2823, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: All are risk factors for shoulder dystocia except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Primigravida

 

Primigravid women are NOT at a higher risk for hsoulder dystocia

 

Let's Discuss the other Options:

 

  • Option A: Previous h/o shoulder dystocia: This increases the risk of a repeat shoulder dystocia
  • Option B: Multiparity: Multiparous women are at a higher risk of shoulder dystocia. This could be as the weight of the fetus tends to increase with every pregnancy
  • Option D: Vacuum delivery: This also increases the risk of shoulder dytocia

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Risk factors for shoulder dystocia include

 

  1. Previous shoulder dystocia
  2. Macrosomia
  3. Diabetes
  4. Obesity
  5. Induced labor
  6. Prolonged labor
  7. Vacuum and forceps (more common with vacuum)
  8. Anencephaly
  9. Multiparity
  10. Post maturity

 

ReF: Page no 469, DC Duttas textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

choices.text: Apply fundal pressure
Perform an episiotomy
Call for additional help
Attempt gentle traction on the baby's head

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is in labor and begins experiencing shoulder dystocia. What is the initial FIRST step in managing this obstetric emergency?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Call for additional help

 

Explanation: In the case of shoulder dystocia, the immediate action should be to call for additional help, including an obstetrician, neonatologist, or additional labor and delivery staff. Prompt assistance is crucial for managing this emergency.

 

Other options:

  • Option A: Applying fundal pressure is not recommended in cases of shoulder dystocia. Fundal pressure can increase the risk of injury to both the mother and the baby, including the risk of uterine rupture or worsening the impaction of the shoulder against the maternal pelvis.
  • Option B: An episiotomy may be performed to aid delivery of the shoulders, but it is not the first step in managing shoulder dystocia. While it can sometimes help, the primary issue in shoulder dystocia is the impaction of the shoulder above the pubic symphysis, not the size of the vaginal opening.
  • Option D: Gentle traction may be attempted, but excessive or improper traction can lead to brachial plexus injuries or clavicular fractures in the newborn. The key is to avoid excessive force and use maneuvers designed to relieve the dystocia by repositioning the baby's shoulders.

 

Educational Objective:

Remember the HELPERR to remember management of shoulder dystocia

H: Call for HELP

E: Episiotomy

L: Legs: McRobert Manuever

P: Supra-pubic pressure

E: Enter the Rotational maneuvers

R: Remove the posterior arm

R: Roll the patient on all 4s

 

Also remember

  • Zavanelli maneuver: Push the head back in and deliver by cesarean
  • Destructive surgeries
    • Cleidotomy: Deliberate fracture of the clavicle
    • Symphysiotomy: Deliberate fracture of the pubic symphysis

 

Ref: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman is in labor, and shoulder dystocia is suspected. Which maternal maneuver is often recommended as a first-line intervention to alleviate shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. McRoberts maneuver

 

Explanation: 

 

The McRoberts maneuver involves hyper-flexing the mother's thighs to the abdomen, which helps to reposition the baby's shoulders and alleviate shoulder dystocia.

 

Shoulder Dystocia Maneuvers

 

  • McRoberts maneuver: -  
    • Hyperflexion of mother’s legs onto the abdomen during child birth
    • This widens the pelvis and flattens the lumbar spine.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Suprapubic pressure: 
    • This pressure should be applied to the posterior aspect of the anterior shoulder, pushing toward the opposite side from where the attendant is positioned.
    • Suprapubic pressure is often used concomitantly with the McRoberts maneuver.
  • Rubin II or posterior pressure on the anterior shoulder, which would bring the fetus in an oblique position with head somewhat towards the vagina
  • Woods’ screw maneuver which leads to turning the anterior shoulder to the posterior and vice versa
  • Gaskin maneuver involves moving the mother to an all-fours position with the back arched, widening the pelvic outlet.
  • Zavanelli maneuver, which involves pushing the fetal head back in with performing a cesarean section. or internal cephalic replacement followed by Cesarean section.
  • Intentional fetal clavicular fracture, which reduces the diameter of the shoulder girdle that is required to pass through the birth canal.
  • Maternal symphysiotomy, which makes the opening of the birth canal laxer by breaking the connective tissue between the two pubes bones facilitating the passage of the shoulders.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember the HELPERR to remember management of shoulder dystocia

 

H: Call for HELP

 

E: Episiotomy

 

L: Legs: McRobert Manuever

 

P: Supra-pubic pressure

 

E: Enter the Rotational maneuvers

 

R: Remove the posterior arm

 

R: Roll the patient on all 4s

 

Also remember

 

  • Zavanelli maneuver: Push the head back in and deliver by cesarean
  • Destructive surgeries
    • Cleidotomy: Deliberate fracture of the clavicle
    • Symphysiotomy: Deliberate fracture of the pubic symphysis

 

Ref: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

choices.text: Attempt to deliver the posterior shoulder first
Apply vacuum extraction to facilitate delivery
Continue with gentle traction on the fetal head
Insert an intrauterine pressure catheter (IUPC)

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman in labor develops shoulder dystocia, and the McRoberts maneuver and suprapubic pressure are unsuccessful. The fetal head is visible, but the shoulders are not descending. What is the next step in managing this situation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Attempt to deliver the posterior shoulder first

 

Explanation: When shoulder dystocia persists and the fetal head is visible, but the shoulders are not descending, attempting to deliver the posterior shoulder first (posterior axillary traction) can help relieve the impaction and facilitate delivery.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B: Using vacuum extraction is not indicated for shoulder dystocia and can be dangerous. The difficulty in shoulder dystocia is not with the delivery of the head, which the vacuum assists with, but with the delivery of the shoulders. Using a vacuum can increase the risk of neonatal injury without resolving the underlying problem.
  • Option C: Continuing with gentle downward traction may be a component of the initial management, but if the standard maneuvers have not been successful, continuing to pull without changing strategy is inappropriate and can cause brachial plexus injury or clavicular fracture.
  • Option D: An IUPC is used to measure the strength and frequency of uterine contractions and is not useful in the management of shoulder dystocia. Shoulder dystocia is a mechanical problem that requires physical maneuvers to resolve, not something that can be assisted by increasing uterine contractions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Remember the HELPERR to remember management of shoulder dystocia

 

H: Call for HELP

E: Episiotomy

L: Legs: McRobert Manuever

P: Supra-pubic pressure

E: Enter the Rotational maneuvers

R: Remove the posterior arm

R: Roll the patient on all 4s

 

Also remember

  • Zavanelli maneuver: Push the head back in and deliver by cesarean
  • Destructive surgeries
    • Cleidotomy: Deliberate fracture of the clavicle
    • Symphysiotomy: Deliberate fracture of the pubic symphysis

Ref: Page no 1288, Williams Obstetric 26th edition
